name: building construction, luxury hotel | building, luxury hotel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/20618/documentation

This dataset represents a tourist accommodation facility located in Lima, Peru. The case study hotel is classed as a luxury hotel (comfort category 5*). It was opened in 2012 as a brand new, stand-alone tourist accommodation facility. The hotel has capacity of 207 rooms (423 beds in total) and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): double/twin (190), junior suite (7), executive suite (9), presidential suite (1). The hotel has 17 floors (13 above the ground and 4 under the ground) which host a lobby, a restaurant, a bar, a spa and event/conference rooms. Laundry is available on site. Parking lot is available on site. The load bearing structure of hotel building is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork. The hotel occupies a plot of 2570 m2 while the gross floor area (GFA) of the hotel is 20260 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hotel is 70% which is equal to 108077 guest nights per year . The case study hotel"s occupancy is in line with the country"s average of 66%; (Source: Hotel News Now 2015. The state of Peru"s tourism, hotels. Available from: http://www.hotelnewsnow.biz/Articles/27650/The-state-of-Perus-tourism-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018).

This dataset is modelled to include the inputs for the construction of a hotel building. This includes:energy and water used in construction, land transformation, building structure and outer building shell, inner walls, roofs, ceiling and windows, doors, floors, finishing and painting, bathroom equipment. Activities include hotel building construction with lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. Maintenance is included only through the consideration of the lifetime of the different exchanges. For example, windows are assumed to have a lifetime of 35 years, therefore the exchange amount is multiplied by 75 years / 35 years=2.14. Hotel building foundation is included in the form of estimates based on the hotel area and construction practices in Peru. 


Activities end with 1 unit of hotel building, including maintenance. Due to data availability, the following building construction processes have been excluded: cables, gutter, drains.
category: F:Construction/41:Construction of buildings/410:Construction of buildings/4100:Construction of buildings

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hotel is based in Lima, Peru.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology in use is considered current.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of construction, the amounts of input material are calculated based on usage across all instances within the hotel building.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Assuming that 0.5 kl per 1 m2 of floor area (GFA) is required in building construction. Source: Crawford et al. 2005. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. Value double checked in McCormack, et al. 2007.

Reference:

Crawford, Robert and Treloar, Graham 2005, An assessment of the energy and water embodied in commercial building construction, in Australian Life Cycle Assessment Conference (4th : 2005 : Novotel, Sydney, N.S.W.), Australian Life Cycle Assessment Society, Sydney, N.S.W., pp. 1-10.

McCormack, et al. 2007. Modelling direct and indirect water requirements of construction. Building research & information. 35(2), 156-162.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Represents here all aluminium parts used in construction of the building structure and walls. Combined of all instance of use across the buidling. Assumed thickness of aluminium is 12 mm. Source: Singh and Verma, 2008. Investigations for deducing wall
thickness of aluminium shell casting
using three dimensional printing. Journal of Achievements in Materials and Manufacturing Engineering, 31(2), 565-569. Available from: http://jamme.acmsse.h2.pl/papers_vol31_2/31259.pdf Accessed 25 March 2018. Assumed density of aluminium is 2700 kg/m3. Source: AmBrSoft Quality Softwares 2018. Materials density table. Available from: http://www.ambrsoft.com/CalcPhysics/Density/Table_2.htm Accessed 25 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to scrap aluminium.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Combined of all instances of use across the building structure, walls and floor (14450m3). Assumed thickness of concrete of 225 mm, Insulation 2011. Thermafloor TF70. INSULATION FOR SOLID CONCRETE AND SUSPENDED GROUND FLOORS. Available from http://kingspaninsulation.co.uk/getattachment/5fdd04b2-e58e-4622-97bb-5861799ab02a/Thermafloor-TF70-pdf.pdf Accessed 23 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout.

Additionally the concrete for foundations is accounted for (30840m3). Estimated value based on the hotel area and construction practices in Peru. The case study hotel has 4 floors of underground parking that occupy 2570 m2 of area and have 3 m of height each. Hotel foundation is then calculated as 2570 m2 x 3 m x 4 = 30840 m3. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste concrete.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). This flow represents ceramic bathroom equipment (washing basin, toilet seat and bath tube). The hotel has 241 washing basins, 238 toilet seats and 103 bath tubes. Washing basins are assumed to weigh 15kg (information taken from IKEA (2018) for the product "TÖRNVIKEN Countertop wash-basin", source retrieved from: http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/products/washstands-taps/wash-basins/t%C3%B6rnviken-countertop-wash-basin-white-art-90291518/, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Toilet seats are assumed to weigh 35kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product "COOKE & LEWIS FABIENNE CLOSE-COUPLED TOILET WITH SOFT CLOSE SEAT", source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-fabienne-close-coupled-toilet-with-soft-close-seat/1142804_BQ.prd?B/R_Toilets_C_CT, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Bath tubes are assumed to weigh 33kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product COOKE & LEWIS CONWAY STEEL RECTANGULAR STRAIGHT BATH (L)1700MM (W)700MM, source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-conway-steel-rectangular-straight-bath-l-1700mm-w-700mm/194437_BQ.prd, accessed 23 March 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to inert waste.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Combined of all instances of use across the building. Assumed thickness of plasterboard 12.5 mm. Source: Practical DYI 2018. Types of plasterboard. Available from: https://www.practicaldiy.com/general-building/plasterboard/plasterboard.php Accessed 23 March 2018. Assumed density of plasterboard 640 kg/m3. Source: British Gypsum 2018. What is the density of Gyproc plasterboards? Available from: http://www.british-gypsum.com/technical-advice/faqs/114-what-is-the-density-of-gyproc-plasterboards Accessed 23 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste gypsum plasterboard.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Assumed service life of 35 years. Source: Asif et al. 2002. LIFE CYCLE OF WINDOW MATERIALS - A COMPARATIVE ASSESSMENT. Available from: http://ohp.parks.ca.gov/pages/1054/files/uk%20window%20frame%20lca.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to used window frame, wood-metal.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Assuming that 1.39 kWh/m3 of diesel is necessary to construct a building. Source: Zabalza et al. 2013. Use of LCA as a Tool for Building Ecodesign. A Case Study of a Low Energy Building in Spain. Energies, 6(8), 3901-3921. Assuming 1 kWh = 3.6 MJ.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Used here in place of marble. Combined of all instances of use across the building. Assumed thickness of marble is 22 mm. Source: Erdly and Schwartz 2004. Building facade maintenance, repair, and inspection. ASTM International, West Conshohocken, USA. Assumed density of marble is 2.7 kg/m3. Source: The Engineering Toolbox 2018. Densities of common solids. Available from: https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/density-solids-d_1265.html Accessed 25 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to inert waste.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). Assumed service life of 40 years. Source: Cobut et al. 2015. The environmental footprint of interior wood doors in non-residential buildings - part 1: life cycle assessment. Journal of Cleaner Production, 109, 232-246. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to used door, outer, wood-alunimium.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Represents here the floor material. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). No data on the type of flooring was provided by the case study hotel so PVC was used as proxy. This is because PVC flooring is most cost-effective for hotels. Source: Mikulski 2015. TOP HOSPITALITY FLOORING OPTIONS FOR HOTELS. Available from: http://www.businessflooring.net/blog/top-hospitality-flooring-options-for-hotels Accessed 16 March 2018. Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls.Assumed density of PVC 2.3 kg/m2. Source: The colour flooring company 2018. VINYL FLOORING TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS. Available from: https://www.colourflooring.co.uk/pages/vinyl-flooring-technical-specifications Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of PVC floors is 40 years. Source: Bowyer et al. 2009. LIFE CYCLE ASSESSMENT OF FLOORING MATERIALS A GUIDE TO INTELLIGENT SELECTION. Doviteil Partners. Available from: http://www.dovetailinc.org/report_pdfs/2009/dovetailfloors0809.pdf Accessed 16 March 2018.  In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to waste PVC.
